metadata.title: Is the Current N95 Respirator Filtration Efficiency Test Sufficient for Evaluating Protection Against Submicrometer Particles Containing SARS-CoV-2?

abstract.text: Previous researchers measured the Overall Filtration Efficiency using sodium 13 chloride testing aerosol with aerosol photometer to analyze the reuse of respirators after 14 sterilization. However, this study showed that the Overall Filtration Efficiency would 15 significantly overestimate the respirators' ability to protect against submicrometer 16 particles containing SARS-CoV-2. For example, after three cycle H2O2 vaporous 17 sterilizations, the most penetrating particle size for the N95 level respirators was from 18 250 nm -500 nm, which carried the peak concentration of the SARS-CoV-2 in 19 hospitals. The Size Specific Filtration Efficiency (250 nm -500 nm) dropped to 20 56%±4%, however, the Overall Filtration Efficiency was still 86%±5%. In order to 21 protect health care personnel adequately, we recommend measuring the Size Specific 2

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102327 doi: medRxiv preprint Introduction 28 Recent studies indicates that aerosol transmission of the severe acute respiratory 29 syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) is plausible since the virus can remain viable and 30 infectious in aerosol form for hours (1, 2) . The actual SARS-CoV-2 size ranges from 60 nm -31 150 nm (3,4,5). The peak concentration of the SARS-CoV-2 in hospitals was found in 250 32 nm -500 nm particles (6). Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and shortage of mask supplies 33 (7), some studies analyzed the reuse of N95/KN95 masks after sterilization by measuring the 34 filtration efficiency using sodium chloride (NaCl) test aerosol (8, 9) . The N95 grade mask 35 should have a minimum filtration efficiency of 95% for 300 nm NaCl aerosols. The light-36 scattering instruments (e.g., aerosol photometer), which are commonly used for filtration 37 efficiency test, are usually limited to measuring aerosol size from 100 nm to 10 µm.
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: However, the count median diameter of the NaCl test aerosol is 75±20 nm with the geometric from 100 nm -250 nm, which is not in the particle size range of containing the peak 43 concentration of the SARS-CoV-2 in hospitals. Therefore, a mask efficient for particles ≤ 44 250 nm may not capture most SARS-CoV-2, and the size specific filtration efficiency is a 45 . The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102327 doi: medRxiv preprint 3 better assessment of the mask's protection ability rather than the overall filtration efficiency 46 to prevent the SARS-CoV-2 transmit via airborne particles. The goal of this demonstration 47 study was to test the effects of multiple sterilization cycles on the size specific filtration 48 efficiency compared to the overall filtration efficiency of KN95 and N95 masks.

The effects of multi-cycle sterilization on the filtration efficiency by aerosol size are 66 . CC-BY-NC 4.0 International license It is made available under a is the author/funder, who has granted medRxiv a license to display the preprint in perpetuity.

The copyright holder for this preprint this version posted May 18, 2020. . https://doi.org/10.1101/2020.05.14.20102327 doi: medRxiv preprint 4 summarized in the Figure 1 . After three H2O2 sterilization cycles, the filtration efficiency for 67 250 nm -500 nm particles dropped from 84%±2% to 68%±3% for KN95, and from 97%±2% 68 to 56%±4% for N95. The differences between two and three cycles were significant for both 69 KN95 (p-value = 0.028±0.037) and N95 (p-value = 0.0009±0.0008). FIGREF2.text: the effects of two-and three-cycle sterilization using vaporous 52 hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) and ultraviolet (UV) germicidal irradiation on the filtration 53 efficiencies by size of KN95 (Civilian Antivirus, Qingdao, Shandong, China) and N95 54 (model 1860, 3M, St Paul, MN, USA) mask. The experimental setup was illustrated in 55 previous study (10). A NaCl aerosol was generated using a Collision Nebulizer (3 jet, CH 56 Technologies, Westwood, NJ, USA) operated at 20 psi using 2% NaCl recommended by 57 NIOSH procedure No. TEB-APR-STP-0059. We tested five samples for each mask. A 58 scanning mobility particle sizer (SMPS, model 3936, TSI Inc., Shoreview, MN, USA) was 59 used to measure the number concentration of test aerosol from 16.8 nm to 514 nm up and 60 down stream of each sample. We conducted a two-sample t-test (with α=0.05 as significance 61 threshold) to compare the mean filtration efficiency of the five samples at each aerosol size 62 between two and three sterilization cycles.

FIGREF4.text: 70the filtration efficiency of KN95 for 250 nm -500 nm particles was 94.4%±1.0% after two 71 cycles, and 95.0%±0.6% after three cycles; and the filtration efficiency of N95 was 72 95.9%±1.4% after two cycles, and 96.9%±0.7% after three cycles. The differences were not 73 statistically significant between two and three cycles for both KN95 (p-value = 0.754±0.187)74    and N95 (p-value = 0.448±0.267).

FIGREF8.text: effects on the filtration efficiencies by aerosol size of different masks. Multi-cycle 94 sterilization with UV appears to have fewer negative effects than H2O2. Limitations include 95 the small variety of mask manufacturers and the limited numbers of samples (n=5) for each 96 mask and only two sterilization techniques evaluated.
